Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesions involving:
- right cerebellum and left optic nerve.

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included Multiple sclerosis.

Agree to also consider:
- NMOSD (AQP4+), MOGAD and Neurosarcoid.

Other possible differentials:
- SLE and Neurosyphilis.
- Also feasible but of low probability: Vasculitis, Susac Syndrome, Sjogren's, ADEM, Behçet's, Lymphoma and Lyme.

The following suggested diagnoses have a low probability of providing a unifying explanation for the full clinical presentation:
- Right cerebellar space-occupying lesion (e.g. low-grade glioma or metastasis) (plausible for unilateral cerebellum; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Ischaemic stroke of the right cerebellar hemisphere (e.g. PICA or SCA territory) (plausible for unilateral cerebellum; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Toxic or metabolic cerebellar degeneration (e.g. alcohol, phenytoin, gluten ataxia, vitamin B12 deficiency) (plausible for unilateral cerebellum; but atypical for strictly unilateral optic nerve involvement)

ft_diagnoses_raw: Clinically isolated syndrome due to central nervous system demyelination
Right cerebellar space-occupying lesion (e.g. low-grade glioma or metastasis)
Ischaemic stroke of the right cerebellar hemisphere (e.g. PICA or SCA territory)
Toxic or metabolic cerebellar degeneration (e.g. alcohol, phenytoin, gluten ataxia, vitamin B12 deficiency)
additional_diagnoses: Right cerebellar space-occupying lesion (e.g. low-grade glioma or metastasis)
Ischaemic stroke of the right cerebellar hemisphere (e.g. PICA or SCA territory)
Toxic or metabolic cerebellar degeneration (e.g. alcohol, phenytoin, gluten ataxia, vitamin B12 deficiency)

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---

- Agree with the suggested MRI including the Brain and Orbits and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands - would potentially inform a diagnosis/details of multiple sclerosis.

To evaluate other differential diagnoses:
- Agree with considering: anti-dsDNA, anti-MOG, ANA, CRP, ENA, ACE, HIV, anti-AQP4, syphilis, ESR.
- Could also consider testing: ANCA, lyme, CSF (flow cytometry and cytology), audiometry, fluorescein angiography.

ft_proposed_investigations: MRI brain and orbits with gadolinium contrast
MRI cervical spine with gadolinium contrast
MRI thoracic spine with gadolinium contrast
Lumbar puncture with CSF cell count and differential
Lumbar puncture with CSF protein and glucose
Lumbar puncture with CSF oligoclonal bands and IgG index
Lumbar puncture with CSF culture and viral PCR as indicated
Optical coherence tomography of optic nerves and maculae
Coeliac serology (tissue transglutaminase IgA and total IgA)
CT scan of chest, abdomen and pelvis for malignancy screening (if paraneoplastic cerebellitis suspected)

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Not appropriate to start treatment immediately.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- This could be a pseudorelapse (exacerbation of an old deficit) rather than a new acute inflammatory relapse, need further clarity in the history of presenting complaint.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

DMTs: Appropriate to consider but delay treatment.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Need a pregnancy test result.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Presentation is highly suggestive of an acute inflammatory demyelinating attack with significant gait and speech impairment
Therapeutic window for maximal benefit of steroids is within the first 2 weeks of symptom onset
No clinical evidence of systemic infection or sepsis on initial assessment
Standard first-line treatment for acute MS, NMOSD and MOGAD relapses while awaiting MRI and serology

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Oral prednisolone taper over 1–2 weeks following IV methylprednisolone
reasons: Initiated after completion of IV pulse to reduce risk of rebound symptoms
Allows gradual withdrawal of corticosteroids and minimises adrenal suppression

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Proton pump inhibitor prophylaxis during corticosteroid therapy
reasons: High-dose steroids increase risk of peptic ulcer disease and gastrointestinal bleeding
Patient has no contraindication to PPI and will be receiving several days of systemic steroids

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Thromboprophylaxis with low-molecular-weight heparin and graduated compression stockings while inpatient
reasons: Ataxic gait and reduced mobility increase risk of venous thromboembolism
High-dose steroids may further increase thrombotic risk

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Physiotherapy and occupational therapy focusing on gait, balance and home safety assessment
reasons: Cerebellar ataxia and unstable tandem gait confer high falls risk
Early rehabilitation improves functional outcomes and independence

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Speech and language therapy assessment and intervention
reasons: Slurred speech suggests cerebellar dysarthria which may impair intelligibility
Early assessment can guide communication strategies and screen for associated swallowing problems

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Initiation of disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis (e.g. ocrelizumab, natalizumab, fingolimod or other agent according to local protocol)
reasons: Requires confirmation of MS diagnosis with MRI and CSF findings and exclusion of NMOSD/MOGAD
Choice of agent depends on disease activity, comorbidities, pregnancy plans and JCV serostatus
Not required emergently during the acute relapse treatment phase

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Long-term immunosuppressive therapy for neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder or MOG-antibody disease (e.g. rituximab, inebilizumab, satralizumab, mycophenolate mofetil)
reasons: Only indicated if aquaporin-4 or MOG antibodies confirm alternative diagnosis to MS
Requires detailed counselling about infection risk, vaccination status and fertility considerations

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Plasma exchange for severe or steroid-refractory relapse
reasons: Reserved for cases with poor response to high-dose corticosteroids or very severe visual or cerebellar deficits
Invasive procedure requiring central venous access and haemodynamic monitoring, so used selectively

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Vitamin D supplementation if deficiency confirmed
reasons: Low vitamin D is associated with increased MS risk and disease activity
Dosing should be tailored to measured serum vitamin D level to avoid toxicity

ft_plan.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Presentation is highly suggestive of an acute inflammatory demyelinating attack with significant gait and speech impairment
Therapeutic window for maximal benefit of steroids is within the first 2 weeks of symptom onset
No clinical evidence of systemic infection or sepsis on initial assessment
Standard first-line treatment for acute MS, NMOSD and MOGAD relapses while awaiting MRI and serology

missing_information: No indication this isn't an exacerbation of an old deficit/pseudorelapse.
A safety screen for patient-specific comorbidities is required to identify contraindications to immunosuppressive therapy.

steroids_evaluation.evaluation_summary:
Not appropriate to start treatment immediately.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- This could be a pseudorelapse (exacerbation of an old deficit) rather than a new acute inflammatory relapse, need further clarity in the history of presenting complaint.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

ft_plan.treatment: Initiation of disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis (e.g. ocrelizumab, natalizumab, fingolimod or other agent according to local protocol)
reasons: Requires confirmation of MS diagnosis with MRI and CSF findings and exclusion of NMOSD/MOGAD
Choice of agent depends on disease activity, comorbidities, pregnancy plans and JCV serostatus
Not required emergently during the acute relapse treatment phase

missing_information: A safety screen for patient-specific comorbidities is required to identify contraindications to immunosuppressive therapy.
